increasingly  concentrated  in  more  vulnerable,  remote,  and  isolated  mountain  areas  in  the  rural  central 
and  western  regions.  This  has  led  the  government  to  prioritize  the  reduction  of  rural–urban,  interior–
coastal  income  inequality  and  improvement  of  rural  livelihoods.  Sustaining  growth  is  vital  for  poverty 
reduction,  but  this  will  not  be  possible  without  addressing  environmental  degradation  and  the  strain  on 
natural resources. Consequently in its 11th Five-Year Plan 2006–2010, the government is committed to 
building  a  harmonious  society  and  a  socialist  market  economy

Following  the  PRC’s  11th  Five-Year  Plan  and  other  national  strategies,  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s

The  proposed  Integrated  Renewable  Biomass  Energy  Development  Sector  Project  supports  both  the 
PRC’s and ADB’s strategic priorities by contributing to a better environment and rural livelihoods through

benefits of the project include (i) replacement of fossil fuel by renewable biomass energy in rural areas to 
achieve a low-carbon economy, (ii) reduction of the adverse impacts of the country’s economic growth on 
global warming by collecting and using methane gas emissions generated from animal biomass waste of 
livestock  farms  and  agroprocessing  plants,  and  (iii) ensured  sustainability  of  the  circular  economy  by 
developing  eco-farming  systems  and  emission  reduction  practices.  The  poverty  and  social  analysis 
shows  that  the  project  will  contribute  to  (i)  an  improved  environment  because  of  replacement  of  fossil

through the use of clean energy and appropriate agricultural waste management.

The  participating  provinces  occupy  an  important  position  in  the  national  economy.  The  gross  domestic

capita  GDP  in  project  areas  in  2007  was  CNY22,410,  which  is  CNY3,476  higher  than  the  national 
average  of  CNY18,934.  This  does  not  mean,  however,  that  all  six  provinces  are  well  off.  The  project 
areas’ average was higher because of the relatively well-off provinces—Jiangsu and Shandong.  

The  per  capita  GDPs  of  Heilongjiang,  Henan,  and  Jiangxi  are  all  lower  than  the  national  average.  The 
lowest is in Jiangxi (CNY12,633). Since 2009, the PRC has adopted the new “low-income poverty line” of 
CNY1,067  per  capita  per  year  as  the  general  poverty  line.  According  to  this  new  poverty  line  in  early 
2009,  about  43.2  million  rural  poor  remain  in  the  PRC  accounting  for  4.2%  of  the  rural  population. 
However,  each  province  has  set  its  own  poverty  standards.  In  Shandong  and  Jiangsu,  an  income  of 
CNY1,000 per capita per year is poor; under CNY1,500 is considered “low-income.” The absolute poverty 
line  is  set  at  annual  per  capita  income  of  CNY360  in  Henan  and  Jiangxi,  and  CNY800  in  Shandong. 
According  to  national  standards  used  in  2008  (CNY683  for  absolute  poverty,  CNY944  for  low-income 
poverty), the project areas account for 1.13 million poor, of which 424,600 are absolute poor and 709,000 
are low-income people. They account for 3% of the total population in the project areas. 

The  participating  provinces  still  face  persistent  poverty,  more  pronounced  in  Henan  and  Jiangxi.  There 
are 101 national poverty counties and 148 provincial poverty counties in the six provinces. The total poor 
population in the project area is 11.3 million, of which 4.2 million live in absolute poverty and 7.1 million 
are categorized low-income families.  

Among  the  142  subprojects  to  be  financed  by  the  project,  22  are  located  in  national  poverty  counties 
accounting for 14.3% of total subprojects; and 44 are in provincial poverty counties accounting for 29% of 
total  subprojects.  Jiangxi  has  the  largest  amount  of  subprojects  in  poverty  counties,  40  in  total, 
accounting for 26% of total subprojects. Among the 11 core subprojects, there are three core subprojects 
located in poverty counties—one in Henan national poverty county and two in Jiangxi provincial poverty 
counties. 

The  socioeconomic  study  shows  that  most  of  the  poverty  in  the  project  areas  was  caused  by  lack  of 
productive  labor  force  in  the  household  and  illness.  Low  income  was  due  to  lack  of  employment 
opportunities and lack of sufficient knowledge or skills to secure good jobs. 

2. Design Features 

The project will benefit farmers in three aspects. First, eco-farming, which is promoted under the project, 
will  bring  greater  economic  benefits  to  the  poor  by  reducing  the  expenses  on  chemical  fertilizer  and 
increasing the price of their agricultural products. It is estimated that about 11,000 poor households will 
benefit from eco-farming, with income increased on average by CNY527 per household. Second, farmers 
will benefit from more secure access to market, better selling prices in some cases, provision of improved 
seeds, and latest skills through contract farming with agro-enterprises that would expand their production 
capacity  under  the  project.  Third,  a  fraction  of  poor  households  will  benefit  from  new  employment 
opportunities  created  under  the  project.  It  is  estimated  that  biogas  plant  construction  will  provide  about 
6,000 temporary job opportunities to the poor, increasing their income by a total of CNY4,000 on average 
over  about  3  months.  During  operation,  about  1,700  poor  farmers  will  receive  relatively  stable 
employment  opportunities  such  as  supplying  agricultural  products  (animal  husbandry)  to  agro-
enterprises.  Their  annual  income  is  expected  to  rise  to  about  CNY13,000  per  person.  To  expand  the 
benefit,  the  project  encourages  local  governments,  agro-enterprises,  the  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Social 
Security, and the All China Women’s Federation to cooperate and provide unskilled jobs (such as 20%) to 
vulnerable groups such as the poor and women. In addition, the project aims to provide agricultural skills 
and biogas management skills training for the vulnerable.
